item.content:encoded: Image: Ascendant Studios/Electronic Arts Developer Ascendant Studios cited poor sales Immortals of Aveum creator Ascendant Studios has laid off nearly half of its staff, according to three people at the studio. item.title: World scale inverse reinforcement learning in Google Maps | Google AI Blog
item.description: Posted by Matt Barnes, Software Engineer, Google Research Routing in Google Maps remains one of our most helpful and frequently used features. Determining the best route from A to B requires makin...
item.content:encoded: Posted by Matt Barnes, Software Engineer, Google Research Routing in Google Maps remains one of our most helpful and frequently used features. Determining the best route from A to B requires making complex trade-offs between factors including the estimated time of arrival (ETA), tolls, directness, surface conditions (e.g., paved, unpaved roads), and user preferences, which vary across transportation mode and local geography. Often, the most natural visibility we have into travelers' preferen...

item.title: A Comprehensive Guide to Pinecone Vector Databases | KDnuggets
item.description: This blog discusses vector databases, specifically pinecone vector databases. A vector database is a type of database that stores data as mathematical vectors, which represent features or attributes. ...
item.content:encoded: This blog discusses vector databases, specifically pinecone vector databases. A vector database is a type of database that stores data as mathematical vectors, which represent features or attributes. These vectors have multiple dimensions, capturing complex data relationships. This allows for efficient similarity and distance calculations, making it useful for tasks like machine learning, data analysis, and recommendation systems.

With step-by-step examples, this guide is perfect for beginners looking to enhance their data management skills.

item.title: Differentially private median and more | Google AI Blog
item.description: Posted by Edith Cohen and Uri Stemmer, Research Scientists, Google Research Differential privacy (DP) is a rigorous mathematical definition of privacy. DP algorithms are randomized to protect use...
item.content:encoded: Posted by Edith Cohen and Uri Stemmer, Research Scientists, Google Research Differential privacy (DP) is a rigorous mathematical definition of privacy. DP algorithms are randomized to protect user data by ensuring that the probability of any particular output is nearly unchanged when a data point is added or removed. Therefore, the output of a DP algorithm does not disclose the presence of any one data point. There has been significant progress in both foundational research and adoption of ...

item.content:encoded: Time Magazine just released its Time 100 AI list, spotlighting 100 key figures in AI across categories such as leaders and innovators. The list aims to highlight the human effort behind AI advancements. The list serves as a snapshot of how mainstream media views the AI landscape, offering a mix of familiar and new names in the field.

item.title: A novel computational fluid dynamics framework for turbulent flow research | Google AI Blog
item.description: Posted by Shantanu Shahane, Software Engineer, and Matthias Ihme, Research Scientist, Athena Team Turbulence is ubiquitous in environmental and engineering fluid flows, and is encountered routinel...
item.content:encoded: Posted by Shantanu Shahane, Software Engineer, and Matthias Ihme, Research Scientist, Athena Team Turbulence is ubiquitous in environmental and engineering fluid flows, and is encountered routinely in everyday life. A better understanding of these turbulent processes could provide valuable insights across a variety of research areas ‚Äî improving the prediction of cloud formation by atmospheric transport and the spreading of wildfires by turbulent energy exchange, understanding sedimentation o...

In multivariate time series forecasting (forecasting multiple variants at the same time), one can split existing methods into ...

item.description: LDCs are categories with two tensor products linked by coherent linear (or weak) distributors. The significance of this theoretical development stems from many situations in logic, theoretical compute...
item.content:encoded: LDCs are categories with two tensor products linked by coherent linear (or weak) distributors. The significance of this theoretical development stems from many situations in logic, theoretical computer science, and category theory where tensor products play a key role.

item.content:encoded: A central idempotent in a monoidal category $(\mathbf{C}, \otimes, I)$ is a way to speak about the "location" of a process taking place in $\mathbf{C}$, but without referring to points, space, or distance.

item.content:encoded: Let's motivate this blog post by first formalizing what a resource theory is. Coecke et al. represent a resource theory in "A mathematical theory of resources" as a symmetric monoidal category (SMC), which is a familiar construction in applied category theory.

item.content:encoded: KDnuggets celebrates its 30th anniversary with month-long initiatives. First, a "Back to Basics" campaign updates foundational data science content for beginners. Second, in partnership with O'Reilly, the "30 for 30" giveaway offers a free ebook daily to newsletter subscribers.

item.title: KDnuggets 30th Anniversary Interview with Founder Gregory Piatetsky-Shapiro | KDnuggets
item.description: Gregory Piatetsky-Shapiro founded KDnuggets 30 years ago, after organizing early workshops on knowledge discovery. In this retrospective interview, he reflects on KDnuggets' growth, key innovations li...
item.content:encoded: Gregory Piatetsky-Shapiro founded KDnuggets 30 years ago, after organizing early workshops on knowledge discovery. In this retrospective interview, he reflects on KDnuggets' growth, key innovations like deep learning, and concerns about AI's societal impact.
